Netflix price hike: How to avoid the 25% rise - and 5 alternative TV packages if you can't The streaming service, which has an estimated 74 million customers worldwide, has announced place to up its prices   Share   Comments By Emma Munbodh 10:00, 23 FEB 2017 Updated 10:12, 23 FEB 2017 Money Netflix fees are on the rise...again (Photo: Getty)     money   If you're one of millions of loyal Netflix customers set to be affected by the £1.50 price hike next month - there are ways to beat the costs - and you have a week to prepare for it.
On 12 April 2016, the popular US streaming service announced it will roll out a rise on subscription fees for its longest-standing members - just 10 months after last year's 50p increase .
The company explained that UK members that signed up for the service when it first launched in 2012 have remained on the 'old' pricing scheme, while new customers have to pay more.
Read More 5 best Netflix alternatives - and more FREE ways to watch your favourite TV shows in the UK But as of May 2016 that legacy pricing will be adjusted, and the 'Standard Netflix' price plan will rise from £5.99 to £7.49 across the board - an increase of £1.50 a month for many users.
Netflix, which broadcasts House of Cards, Master of None and Pretty Little Liars exclusively, reported 74.76 million streaming customers worldwide at the end of 2015 - estimating its first-quarter streaming revenue in 2016 to be around $1.8 billion.
How will the Nexflix price hike affect me? If you signed up for 'Standard Netflix' at the start, you would have been charged £5.99 a month, which entitled you to HD Netflix across up to two screens simultaneously.
This package now costs £7.49 a month. This month you'll receive an email from Netflix making you aware of this update.
"Later this month, members in the UK will begin to be ungrandfathered," a Netflix spokesperson said.
"Beginning May, the price update is rolling out elsewhere based on member billing periods.
"Impacted members will be clearly notified by email and within the service, so that they have time to decide which plan/price point works best for them."
A Netflix spokesperson says: "The prices taking effect were previously announced in May 2014 and follow a two-year period of holding prices to the previous level as a thank you to members."
How much does Netflix cost in the UK? ' Basic' membership: £5.99/month. One screen at a time; includes standard definition (SD) streaming only.
'Standard' membership: £7.49/month. Stream to two screens simultaneously; includes HD streaming.
'Premium' membership: £8.99/month. Stream to four screens at a time; includes streaming at 4K resolution.
How to avoid the price hike Netflix currently offers two other price plans alongside the aforementioned 'Standard' package.
One option is to switch to the £5.99 a month 'basic' package (see breakdown above) - however this limits you to only one screen at a time and only standard definition picture quality.
Alternatively, you can pay £8.99 for the Premium bundle that gets you up to four screens at once and the ability to watch in 4K.
Read More Netflix How to avoid Netflix price rises Netflix library shrinks Hidden Netflix codes Netflix in March 5 UK alternatives to Netflix (Photo: Getty) If you're divorcing Netflix, here are some alternatives to consider, along with how much they cost a month.
Amazon Instant Video : £79 a year and includes free one-hour/one-day delivery on Amazon items, access to thousands of e-books, films, TV shows (including Top Gear) and songs though Amazon's extensive media library. See our Amazon Prime FAQ to discover more.
Now TV : Invest in a one off box at around £20 ( currently £19.99 with a free 3 months Sky Entertainment Pass at Argos ). The box will transform your TV into a smart device. Users can then purchase 24-hour and 30-day Sky passes ad hoc for football matches, movies and entertainment from around £5.99 one-off and contract free.
YouTube : Free (when you sign up for a free Google account). Although limited, You Tube has thousands of TV shows on its platform which you can watch without any obligations and under no time constraints.
Sky TV : Sky's Original TV bundle starts at £20 - and you can currently get a free 32'' LG TV, Samsung Galaxy Tab E or £100 reward for signing up. The package includes catch up TV, Sky+ and Sky Go, as well as usual suspects Sky Atlantic and itv Encore. Find out more about the Sky TV Original Package here.
Freeview Order a one-off box - this Manhattan Plaza Smart Freeview HD Digital TV Receiver is now £43 at Tesco Direct and you can immediately enjoy over 50 TV and 24 radio channels with 11 in HD, as well as access to YouTube, BBC iPlayer and more on-demand features. Most TVs purchased after 2014 will already have built-in Freeview, however if you have an older television, you can upgrade with a Freeview box - simply connect it up to your TV with a scart lead.
